My assignment for module \# 13 was to explore how to use ChatGPT to create a data visualization and to reflect on the process. This gave me hands-on experience with AI tools in visual analytics and helped me critically assess their usefulness.

1.  Register for ChatGPT (if you donâ€™t already have an account):

I have an account for ChatGPT. Additionally, I explored the interface and familiarized myself with how ChatGPT works.

2.  Generate a Visualization Using ChatGPT:

The dataset I wanted to visualize in ChatGPT was the mtcars dataset.

This is the generated code that I copied into my RStudio environment:

[![](mod13gptcode.png)](mod13gptcode.png)

This code creates a scatterplot using ggplot2, emphasizing good cars based on miles per gallon and weight.

Here is the resulting visualization from running the generated code in the RStudio environment:

```{r}
# Load libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)

# Define "good cars" as those with mpg > 20 and wt < 3.0
mtcars$good_car <- ifelse(mtcars$mpg > 20 & mtcars$wt < 3.0, "Good Car", "Other")

# Create the visualization
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg, color = good_car, size = hp)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.8) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("Good Car" = "#2ecc71", "Other" = "#e74c3c")) +
  labs(
    title = "Fuel Efficiency vs. Weight in Cars",
    subtitle = "Highlighting 'Good Cars' (mpg > 20 & weight < 3.0)",
    x = "Weight (1000 lbs)",
    y = "Miles per Gallon (mpg)",
    color = "Car Type",
    size = "Horsepower"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
    legend.position = "bottom"
  )
```

This is a good visualization, but it could use clearer visuals and better aesthetics.

4.  Publish on Your Blog

Here is my visualization image in a .png file format:

[![](m13refinedimage.png)](m13refinedimage.png)

I started to create an mtcars dataset visualization from ChatGPT by providing a prompt that states, "Write R code using ggplot2 to create a visualization from the mtcars dataset. I want it to focus on making a graph/chart of good cars." As a result, ChatGPT provided code to load the libraries, define good cars, and create the visualization. Then it gave me a list of bullet points outlining what the code does: color-coding vehicles, using size to represent horsepower, adding a clear title, subtitle, and legend, and applying a clean theme for aesthetic purposes. When I ran the code and previewed the image, I noticed that the visualization aimed to consider high miles per gallon and lighter weight in determining whether a car was good.

The challenges I faced in creating the generated visualization all stemmed from bias. The most considerable bias in ChatGPT's visualization came from how it defined good cars. The phrase mpg \> 20 and wt \< 3.0 assumes that fuel efficiency and low weight are the only measures of a good car. However, other definitions could be just as valid, such as a good car for a racer being one with high horsepower and acceleration, but not high mpg. There was also bias in the colors, as red mostly conveys "bad" or "danger" rather than "other," which is not appropriate for evaluating which car group is better. In the end, the visualization I modified worked very well, as my improved version removes most of the bias by using a better color palette, simplified labels, and well-structured layout choices.

I think AI feels like a collaborator in visualization design, but the information it generates needs careful clarification from the user since it can make mistakes and contain bias from some of its training data. It is excellent at generating some practical design ideas, but it is essential to remain ethical and intentional about whether the information is accurate.
